Monoid
A set $M$ with a law of composition $\sigma: M \times M \longrightarrow M$ is called a monoid if $\sigma$ is associative and $M$ admits a unit element with respect to $\sigma$.
Normal Subgroup
A subgroup $H \subset G$ is called a normal subgroup of $G$ if $aH = Ha$ for all $a \in G$, i.e., if for each element $a \in G$ the associated left and right cosets of $H$ in $G$ coincide.
Commutative Ring
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
Product of Ideals

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Greatest common divisor

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.
Submodule
Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
Algebraically closed field

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Solvable group

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
p-Sylow subgroup

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.
Tensor
A tensor is a multi-dimensional array, generalizing the concept of a scalar, vector and matrix.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The product of ideals is defined in terms of ideals in a ring. Therefore, the concept of an ideal and a ring must be defined to understand the product of ideals.
The greatest common divisor is defined in terms of divisibility within a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand the greatest common divisor.
A solvable group is defined in terms of a chain of subgroups and normal subgroups. Therefore, the concept of a group and normal subgroups must be defined to understand a solvable group.
